title: RECOMMENDATIONS ON FORMULA SUPPLY IN THE HOSPITAL
items.abstract:
<jats:p>In the process of preparing a new revision of the manual, Standards and Recommendations for Hospital Care of Newborn Infants, the Committee on Fetus and Newborn established a new set of standards concerning preparation and handling of formula supply in the hospital.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Because of the current interest in formula supply, brought about by recent technological changes, the Committee decided to issue the standards as a separate statement. It will later appear as a section in the revised edition of Standards and Recommendations of Hospital Care of Newborn Infants.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Responsibility for the policies regarding feeding of infants in nurseries must be assigned to designated members of the medical staff. They make all decisions about prescription, acceptability, preparation, and distribution of formula. They also set up control and review procedures.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Three principal methods for providing formula to nursery infants are currently available in the United States. Their relative efficacies cannot be evaluated at this time, but all should meet basic standardized requirements.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>The three methods are: (1) preparation of the formula entirely in the hospital formula room; (2) final preparation of formula in the hospital from components, pre-sterilized, packaged, and delivered by an ourside source; (3) use of individually packaged pre-steriuized formula delivered by an outside source.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>In providing formula for infants, attention must be given to the following:</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Facilities</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Personnel and their responsibilities</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Formula preparation</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Safety standards and quality control</jats:p>
               <jats:p>A. Facilities</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Facilities necessary for the preparation of formula depend on the method used in providing the formula.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>1. Formula Room</jats:p>

The influence of varying phosphorus and water supply on the growth and yield of a swamp rice variety (Oryza sativa L.)
items.abstract: <jats:p>1. ‘Wet’ soil plants had greater tiller and leaf number, and were also taller than ‘dry’ soil plants.</jats:p><jats:p>2. The straw and grain dry weight, and grain weight as percentage of straw weight, were greater in ‘wet’ soil plants than in ‘dry’ soil ones.</jats:p><jats:p>3. Wet soil hastened the time of ear emergence.</jats:p><jats:p>4. Increasing the phosphate supply, on the whole, tended to increase the tiller and leaf number, weight of straw and grain and also hastened time of ear emergence.</jats:p><jats:p>5. Under ‘wet’ soil conditions high phosphate application is not necessary.</jats:p><jats:p>6. The yield of grain at high phosphate level of plants grown on ‘dry’ soil is significantly lower than the yield from those grown on ‘wet’ soil with low phosphate application. This suggested that under ‘dry’ soil conditions availability of nitrogen, as well as of phosphorus, is a limiting factor.</jats:p>
